title: Meticulous
definition: Showing great attention to detail; very careful and precise.
phrase: the designs are hand-glazed with meticulous care
swords: careful, conscientious, diligent, ultra-careful, scrupulous, punctilious, painstaking, demanding, exacting, accurate, correct
examples: 'he had always been so meticulous about his appearance'

title: Erudite
definition: Having or showing great knowledge or learning.
phrase: Ken could turn any conversation into an erudite discussion
swords: learned, scholarly, well educated, knowledgeable, well read, widely read, well versed, well informed, lettered, cultured, cultivated, civilized, intellectual
examples:
'she was very erudite'
'The Clinton debate was, it turned out, an unusually erudite discussion.'

title: Fastidious
swords: scrupulous, punctilious, painstaking, meticulous, assiduous, sedulous, perfectionist, fussy, finicky, dainty, over-particular
examples:
'The central characters are fastidious, scrupulous and articulate.'
'Aside from this fastidious attention to detail, the designer's work has few distinguishing features.'

title: Euphoric
definition: Characterized by or feeling intense excitement and happiness.
phrase: The atmosphere was euphoric even before we took the lead.
swords: elated, happy, joyful, joyous, delighted, gleeful, excited, exhilarated, animated, jubilant, exultant, ecstatic, blissful
examples: 'You want to know when I'm happy or sad, tired, glad, euphoric, if I just got piece, whatever.'

title: Enigma
definition: A person or thing that is mysterious or difficult to understand.
phrase: What is left is the puzzle and the enigma that we need to figure out.
swords: mystery, puzzle, riddle, conundrum, paradox, problem, unsolved problem, question, question mark, quandary
examples: 'It is often felt that death is an enigma, perhaps the ultimate mystery.'

title: Pedant
definition: a person who is excessively concerned with minor details and rules or with displaying academic learning.
phrase: The questioner is shouted down, accused of being a grammatical pedant.
swords: dogmatist, purist, literalist, formalist, doctrinaire; precisionist, perfectionist
examples: 'I like that sentence and I don't care what grammatical pedants think.'

title: Abeyance
definition: A state of temporary disuse or suspension.
phrase: matters were held in abeyance pending further enquiries
swords: suspension, a state of suspension, a state of dormancy, a state of latency, a state of uncertainty, suspense, remission, reserve
examples: 'This meant escalation of the pain that had been held in abeyance.'

title: Pragmatic
definition: Dealing with things sensibly and realistically in a way that is based on practical rather than theoretical considerations.
swords: down-to-earth, earthy, hardheaded, matter-of-fact, practical, realistic.
examples: 'All three authors point out that as a composer Stravinsky was very pragmatic.'

title: Bolster
phrase: Place a firm bolster against the wall.
swords: strengthen, support, reinforce, make stronger, boost, fortify, give a boost to
examples:
'They took high premiums to bolster up the funds.'
'the fall in interest rates is starting to bolster confidence'

title: Soporific
definition: Tending to induce drowsiness or sleep.
phrase: the motion of the train had a somewhat soporific effect.
swords: sleep-inducing, somnolent, sedative, calmative, tranquillizing, narcotic, opiate, drowsy, sleepy, somniferous
examples:
'some medicine made her soporific'
'Instead, I stood mesmerised by his soporific chanting.'

title: Fervid
definition: intensely enthusiastic or passionate, especially to an excessive degree.
swords: ardent, blazing, burning, charged, emotional, hot-blooded, incandescent, intense, passional, passionate
examples: 'I don't have the feeling that he is a fervid prosecutor in the sense that he thinks that anyone accused of something must be guilty.'

title: Auspicious
definition: brief and to the point; effectively cut short.
phrase: Jessica is so talkative that her sister thought the situation warranted conciseness, and her being laconic.
swords: favourable, propitious, promising, full of promise, bright, rosy, good, optimistic, hopeful, encouraging
examples:
'This is an auspicious moment for our company,â€™ says its co-founder.'
'It was not an auspicious moment to make their dream a reality.'

title: Engender
phrase: it was not the most auspicious moment to hold an election.
swords: produce, create, generate, arouse, rouse, provoke, incite, kindle, trigger
examples:
'It engenders feelings of belief in what can be achieved.'
'Many of these changes engender anxiety and fear.'

title: Aberrant
phrase: this somewhat aberrant behaviour requires an explanation.
swords: abnormal, anomalous, atypical, especial, exceeding, exceptional, extraordinary, freak, odd, peculiar, phenomenal, rare, singular, uncommon, unique, unusual
examples:
'This year for some aberrant reason, I feel like watching, so let's all watch together.'
'In fact, it covers two of my many aberrant fields of interest.'

title: Ameliorate
phrase: Increase in penalties and effective awareness programs would ameliorate the growing pollution levels and there by global warming it may have generated.
swords: alleviate, lighten, mitigate, amend, help, improve, meliorate, relieve, upgrade, step up
examples:
'the reform did much to ameliorate living standards'
'The humour ameliorates the violence in the statement.'

title: Laconic
definition: brief and to the point; effectively cut short.
phrase: Jessica is so talkative that her sister thought the situation warranted conciseness, and her being laconic.
swords: brief, concise, terse, succinct, short, economical, elliptical, crisp, pithy, to the point, incisive, short and sweet, compendious
examples:
'The problem is likely to be, at least in part, Hilberg's laconic style.'
'his laconic reply suggested a lack of interest in the topic.'

title: Profound
phrase: 'The experience had a very profound effect on me, both emotionally and spiritually.'
swords: heartfelt, intense, keen, great, very great, extreme
examples:
'Such films can never have a profound influence on the viewers, he says'.
'I think it has quite profound implications for us as human beings.'

title: Abate
definition: become less intense or widespread; to reduce; lessen; diminish.
swords: decrease, lessen, diminish, reduce, lower, dampen
examples:
'nothing abated his crusading zeal.'
'energy efficiency may be the quickest way to abate emissions of carbon dioxide.'
